content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle is well-designed. I like this puzzle. It's perfect!

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great Puzzle! Well done.

Please improve the winning condition, especially the word "immediately". Now it is not clear what happens when a player plays his last card (then he has zero thus he lost) or is snap condition checked for his last card an he can still win the pot and save himself.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Perfect for me!

I believe your code is wrong: line 46 should be snap(pile[-2], pile[-1]) instead of snap(pile[-1], pile[-2]). I get a different result than you for about half the cases.

Consider changing the stub to write Winner: Player 1/Player 2 to better match expected output.

Updates:
- Included the suit precedence for decision on snap winner.
- Removed: (This is a slightly altered version of the classic game Snap - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snap_(card_game)) - Making the statement slightly smaller.
- Updated cases to include edge cases and higher snap counts.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Tag should be Queue instead of Priority Queue.

I would move {{A}} in the Cards section to either be at the front or at the back of the array, as its value is usually between the King and the 2 in card games, even if it is irrelevant in snap.

I find it unfortunate for the suits to not be used. An idea would be to say that when a SNAP happens, the player with the best suit is the quickest to say it (following order H > D > C > S). i.e. if player1 plays 3D and then player2 plays 3C, player1 is the one snapping the central pile.

I think it is a good puzzle to introduce Queues and Stacks containers.
good

I'm not sure if the results is right some tests if player 2 out of card then player 1 play his card then wins...
and in other tests like snapless if player 1out of cards player 2 wins without playing another card..

so I don't know if it right or wrong

Goal / Input / Constraints
* Please remove the last three constraints regarding "card", "rank" and "suit", and then:
  ‚Ä¢ Mention "52 card deck" (not "pack deck") in the Goal section.
  ‚Ä¢ Explain "rank" and "suit" in the Goal section (also note that the Constraints section describes "10" as a digit but it isn't).
  ‚Ä¢ List the shorthand notation (D, H, S, C, A, J, Q, K) used for this puzzle in the Goal section.
  ‚Ä¢ Mention that "[[card]]" is in the form of [[Rank]][[Suit]] in the Input section.

* Introduce the term "rank" at the beginning (see my previous point) instead of defining it only when explaining snaps.

Goal / Output / Cases / Solution / Constraints
* Consider whether you want to include test cases for games ending in a tie.
  ‚Ä¢ If yes, please add the relevant explanation to the Goal section, adjust the Output section and solution code accordingly, and add those cases.
  ‚Ä¢ If not, please state that the cases have been designed to guarantee that there will always be a winner (no ties).
  
* Examples of ties (T = 10):

(1)
Player 1: A3579JK2468TQA3579JK2468TQ
Player 2: 2468TQA3579JK2468TQA3579JK

(2)
Player 1: A23579JK468TQA3579JK2468TQ
Player 2: A2468TQ3579JK2468TQA3579JK

(3)
Player 1: no cards
Player 2: no cards

Goal
* Explain what a court card is. Better yet, since the statement already mentions that a snap occurs when the ranks match, it's clearer to give direct examples instead of introducing the term "court card" (e.g. {{A}} matches {{A}}, {{6}} matches {{6}}, {{Q}} matches {{Q}}).

* Just a note: the original wording "court cards only match with the same court card" could be confusing, as it might imply that suits must also match, though the subsequent examples clarify this isn't the case.

* Consider changing "LAST" to "MATCHING".

Input
* Please delete the last sentence.

* Next m Lines: Please add "from top to bottom".

* Next n Lines: Please add "from top to bottom".

Output
* Please exclude "/" from the {{constant}} format.

Constraints
* 1st constraint: Please add ", [[m]] + [[n]]" after "[[n]]".

Thanks.

Updated, thank you!

- I decided not to include draws as technically unless they both have zero cards it won't be a draw as a player would run out of cards before the other.

Let me know if you think anything needs altering üôÇ

Could you provide which tests you're referring to that "player 2 out of card then player 1 play his card".

Can I also check that you're using the "That same player will also take the next turn and the turn order continues as described above." rule?

As in the example, player 1 plays their last card but gets Snap so claims the 7 cards in the pile, then it's their turn again so plays a card leaving them with 6 cards while player 2 plays their last card.

Very true, updated both.

I like your idea for suits to be used - I will update the statement and code.

Thanks!
Ah oops... Should be fixed now.
I have added information that hopefully makes that more clear.
Nope. You don't use the suit anymore ? The previous code was better with just the modification I mentioned to do.

I copy and paste the wrong version ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
I'll fix tomorrow as I've updated the cases and need to redo them.
Been there, done that :)

I have updated it and `should` be good now...

I have also changed it slightly specifying how the cards are claimed, in terms of face-up or face-down, as it wasn't explicitly told before, so you may need to alter you code. I think the changes match the physcial game better now.

I don't think your modification was correct as my function didn't change the turn if the opposite player won the snap, when it should have. But I should have that fixed now ü§û

Let me know your thoughts on the changes, if the example is required or not and anything else (hopefully not telling me I've done something wrong again ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è) üôÇ

Seems good, I pass all the cases with same result as you after a little tweaking.

Changes make it so the central pile now behaves like a queue too instead of a stack (not good or bad, just fyi).

Small typo, please change "Decks are held by plays.." to "Decks are held by players".

Example is useful, I would keep it.

In addition to the typo pointed out by @yhuberla,

Cases
* Clutch Save (Test 4): "8S" appears in both players' decks.

Thanks.

Both updated, thank you!

I have a check for duplicate cards in the test case generator... No idea how that's happened ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Added a few extra test cases to test for: Playing your last card and losing 'Almost Clutch Save' and a few extra standard with higher snaps counts.

If no issues are found with those, I think I have everything covered and would move it to 'Ready'.
I get the same result as you for all test cases.

Ah, you're absolutely right. There will never be ties, since it's impossible for both players to run out of cards at the same time (except in the no-card scenario).

Just one point:

Input
* The text uses "player 1's deck" and "player 2's deck" with "the" in some places but without it in others. Please choose one form and use it throughout.

Thanks.

Updated to consistent form.

It's possible to have ties/infinite loops with cases such as:
A: 355 / 33 / 5455 / 77655
B: 553 / 33 / 4454 / 77554
That I considered adding as ties but then I thought it would bring it to a Medium and I'd like it to be a Easy.

Whether adding ties and potentially extra rules or players makes it interesting enough for a medium part 2, who knows...

Oops, you got me again üòÜ

I'm not sure whether adding ties and extra rules would make it interesting enough for a part 2. One thing to keep in mind is that if the solution to part 2 is just a few lines added to that of part 1, it might be better to keep it as a single puzzle (either with or without the extra elements) rather than splitting it into two.
